AdditionalFields.Value: Tumor Biology,Molecular/Cellular Biology and Genetics,Tumor Microenvironment

Description: Cancer is a systemic disease that involves collaboration between transformed and non-transformed cells.  It is therefore not surprising that the tumor microenvironment (TME) is recognized as a central player in cancer risk, onset, and progression.  In order to design means for assertively targeting the TME and harnessing its natural tumor suppressive function, a comprehensive understanding of the ever-changing TME is needed.  This educational session is designed to use pancreatic cancer as an example of a TME avid solid cancer and provide the audience with tools that can broaden our understanding of the TME as it regards to: 1- the establishment and regulation of the TME; 2- the interplay between various TME components; and 3- the role that the TME modulating-unit (i.e., cancer-associated fibroblasts and self-generated extracellular matrix) plays in supporting or deterring tumorigenesis alone or in response to anti-tumor intended interventions.
Title: Targeting the TME
